elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0015">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para id="sp0030" view="all">Common tetrazolate bridged triad structural building units. (a and b) Variants of the typical M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ-O) cluster. (c) Incorporation of sulfate anion as a capping ligand in the trinuclear core. (d and e) The triad cores of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(3-pyrHtet-O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)] and [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(3-pyrtet)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)]. (f) The building unit of [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(4-pt)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)], where phosphate provides a μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-oxygen donor at the center of a cobalt triad.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 3

Common tetrazolate bridged triad structural building units. (a and b) Variants of the typical M3(μ-O) cluster. (c) Incorporation of sulfate anion as a capping ligand in the trinuclear core. (d and e) The triad cores of [Cu3(OH)3(H2O)3(3-pyrHtet-O)3(SO4)] and [Cu3(OH)2(H2O)3(3-pyrtet)2(SO4)]. (f) The building unit of [Co3(4-pt)3(PO4)], where phosphate provides a μ3-oxygen donor at the center of a cobalt triad.

<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Hydrothermal reactions of a Co(II) salt, 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole and a phosphate source provided the three-dimensional materials [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(4-pt)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(4-pt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HOPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). A view in the <ce:italic>ab</ce:italic>-plane of the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is shown.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
Hydrothermal reactions of a Co(II) salt, 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole and a phosphate source provided the three-dimensional materials [Co3(4-pt)3(PO4)] (1) and [Co3(H2O)4(4-pt)2(HOPO3)2] (2). A view in the ab-plane of the structure of 1 is shown.

<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">► Hydrothermal synthesis of Co(II)/pyridyltetrazolate/phosphate materials. ► Structural study of Co(II) phases with trinuclear secondary building units. ► Coordination modes of the 4-pyridyltetrazolate ligand. ► A novel variant of the {M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O)(azolate)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>} secondary building unit.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights
► Hydrothermal synthesis of Co(II)/pyridyltetrazolate/phosphate materials. ► Structural study of Co(II) phases with trinuclear secondary building units. ► Coordination modes of the 4-pyridyltetrazolate ligand. ► A novel variant of the {M3(μ3-O)(azolate)3} secondary building unit.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">The hydrothermal reactions of a cobalt(II) salt and 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole in the presence of phosphate provided two three-dimensional materials of the M(II)/azolate/anion family [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(4-pt)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(4-pt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HOPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (M(II)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Co; azolate<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole or 4-Hpt; and anion<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and HPO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)). The structures are characterized by the incorporation of metal cluster secondary building units (SBU). The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> features a variant of the common {M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O)} sbu with the central bridging ligand provided by a phosphate oxygen rather than the more common oxo- or hydroxy-ligand. These trinuclear units are bridged through the remaining phosphate oxygen donors into chains which are in turn linked through the pyridyltetrazolate ligands into the framework structure. In the case of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, {Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">6+</ce:sup> linear trinuclear secondary building units are linked to four adjacent clusters through {HOPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> tetrahedra to generate cobalt(II)-hydrogen phosphate layers, which are linked through the 4-pt ligands into the overall framework.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
The hydrothermal reactions of a cobalt(II) salt and 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole in the presence of phosphate provided two three-dimensional materials of the M(II)/azolate/anion family [Co3(4-pt)3(PO4)] (1) and [Co3(H2O)4(4-pt)2(HOPO3)2] (2) (M(II)=Co; azolate=5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole or 4-Hpt; and anion=PO4
3− (1) and HPO4
2− (2)). The structures are characterized by the incorporation of metal cluster secondary building units (SBU). The structure of 1 features a variant of the common {M3(μ3-O)} sbu with the central bridging ligand provided by a phosphate oxygen rather than the more common oxo- or hydroxy-ligand. These trinuclear units are bridged through the remaining phosphate oxygen donors into chains which are in turn linked through the pyridyltetrazolate ligands into the framework structure. In the case of compound 2, {Co3(H2O)4}6+ linear trinuclear secondary building units are linked to four adjacent clusters through {HOPO3}2− tetrahedra to generate cobalt(II)-hydrogen phosphate layers, which are linked through the 4-pt ligands into the overall framework.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Metal organic frameworks are enjoying widespread contemporary interest by virtue of their applications in areas of catalysis, optical materials, membranes, and sorption . The diversity of the properties of these materials reflects a vast compositional range, and provides potential for design of novel functional materials where properties from both the inorganic and organic realms can combine in a complimentary fashion . This combination of features unique to both the inorganic and organic components can lead to unusual structures with novel properties and provides an avenue for design of potentially multifunctional materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Metal organic frameworks are enjoying widespread contemporary interest by virtue of their applications in areas of catalysis, optical materials, membranes, and sorption . The diversity of the properties of these materials reflects a vast compositional range, and provides potential for design of novel functional materials where properties from both the inorganic and organic realms can combine in a complimentary fashion . This combination of features unique to both the inorganic and organic components can lead to unusual structures with novel properties and provides an avenue for design of potentially multifunctional materials.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In such a design, metal atoms or clusters serve as nodes from which flexible organic ligands act as tethers. A variety of organic linkers have been investigated, with materials featuring carboxylate and pyridine tethers showing the most significant development . In designing multifunctional materials, it can be advantageous to investigate the coordination chemistry of ligands exhibiting an ability to bridge metal ions to afford polynuclear compounds, such as the polyazaheteroaromatic family of which pyrazole, imidazole, triazole, and their derivatives are representative. Recent investigations of the coordination compounds of azole-containing linkers have resulted in complexes that exhibit interesting properties due to the ability of the azolate ligand to bridge multiple metal centers in a bi-, tri-, and tetra-dentate modes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In such a design, metal atoms or clusters serve as nodes from which flexible organic ligands act as tethers. A variety of organic linkers have been investigated, with materials featuring carboxylate and pyridine tethers showing the most significant development . In designing multifunctional materials, it can be advantageous to investigate the coordination chemistry of ligands exhibiting an ability to bridge metal ions to afford polynuclear compounds, such as the polyazaheteroaromatic family of which pyrazole, imidazole, triazole, and their derivatives are representative. Recent investigations of the coordination compounds of azole-containing linkers have resulted in complexes that exhibit interesting properties due to the ability of the azolate ligand to bridge multiple metal centers in a bi-, tri-, and tetra-dentate modes .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">All chemicals were used as obtained without further purification: cobalt(II) phosphate hydrate, cobalt (II) acetate tetrahydrate, and phosphoric acid were purchased from Aldrich. 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole was prepared by the “click” chemistry approach using zinc catalysis in aqueous solution or by the use of modified montmorillonite K-10 . All hydrothermal syntheses were carried out in 23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL poly-(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. The reactants were stirred briefly, and the initial pH was measured before heating. Water was distilled above 3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MΩ in-housing using a Barnstead model 525 Biopure distilled water center. The initial and final pH values of each reaction were measured using color pHast sticks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental
All chemicals were used as obtained without further purification: cobalt(II) phosphate hydrate, cobalt (II) acetate tetrahydrate, and phosphoric acid were purchased from Aldrich. 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole was prepared by the “click” chemistry approach using zinc catalysis in aqueous solution or by the use of modified montmorillonite K-10 . All hydrothermal syntheses were carried out in 23mL poly-(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. The reactants were stirred briefly, and the initial pH was measured before heating. Water was distilled above 3.0MΩ in-housing using a Barnstead model 525 Biopure distilled water center. The initial and final pH values of each reaction were measured using color pHast sticks.

Purple crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in 10% yield. Synthesis of [Co3(4-pt)3PO4] (1)
A mixture of Co3(PO4)2·H2O (85.5mg, 0.222mmol), 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole (34.4mg, .236mmol), and H2O (10.00g, 556mmol) in the mole ration 1.00:1.07:2500 was stirred briefly before heating to 180°C for 48h (initial and final pH values of 3.2 and 2.8, respectively). Purple crystals of 1, suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in 10% yield. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3065(w), 1626(s), 1557(w), 1454(m), 1380(w), 1237(w), 1227(w), 1077(s), 1013(s), 923(s), 845(m), 758(s), 732(m), 719(m), 579(s), 543(w). Anal. Calc. for C18Co3H12N15PO4: C, 30.4; H, 1.69; N, 29.6. Found: Co, 25.4; C, 29.9; H, 1.56; N, 29.3%.

Purple crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in 5–10% yield. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3498(b), 12294(w), 1110(m), 1012(m), 874(w), 756(m) 581(m), 530(w), 458(w). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>: C, 19.7; H, 2.47; N, 19.1. Found: C, 19.4; H, 2.22; N, 18.9%.</ce:para>

Synthesis of [Co3(4-pt)2(H2O)4(PO4H)2] (2)
A mixture of Co(C2H3O2)2 (41.2mg, 0.165mmol), 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole (34.4mg, .236mmol), H2O (10.00g, 556mmol), and H3PO4 (50μL 0.860mmol), in the mole ratio 1.00:1.43:3370:5.20 was stirred briefly before heating to 200°C for 48h (initial and final pH values of 2.3 and 2.1 respectively). Purple crystals of 2, suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in 5–10% yield. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3498(b), 12294(w), 1110(m), 1012(m), 874(w), 756(m) 581(m), 530(w), 458(w). Anal. Calc. for C12Co3H18N10P2O12: C, 19.7; H, 2.47; N, 19.1. Found: C, 19.4; H, 2.22; N, 18.9%.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray Crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Structural measurements were performed on a Bruker-AXS SMART-CCD diffractometer at low temperature (90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (Mo Kα<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) . The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and absorption using <ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps>
. The structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. After all of the non-hydrogen atoms had been located, the model was refined against <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, initially using isotropic and later anisotropic thermal displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined isotropically. Neutral atom scattering coefficients and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from the <ce:italic>International Tables</ce:italic>, Vol. C. All calculations were performed using <ce:small-caps>shelxtl</ce:small-caps> crystallographic software packages . The structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was solved in the non-centrosymmetric space group <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>3. Attempts to refine the structure in the centrosymmetric alternative were unsuccessful. Examination of the results with <ce:small-caps>platon</ce:small-caps> also suggested that the space group assignment was correct. Finally, the Flack parameter of 0.04(4) is consistent with the non-centrosymmetric space group. The pyridyl group of this structure is statistically disordered over two sites, rotating by ca. 35° about the N1–C3 vector, with approximate populations of 0.80:0.20.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography
Structural measurements were performed on a Bruker-AXS SMART-CCD diffractometer at low temperature (90K) using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (Mo Kα=0.71073Å) . The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and absorption using sadabs
. The structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. After all of the non-hydrogen atoms had been located, the model was refined against F
2, initially using isotropic and later anisotropic thermal displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined isotropically. Neutral atom scattering coefficients and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from the International Tables, Vol. C. All calculations were performed using shelxtl crystallographic software packages . The structure of compound 1 was solved in the non-centrosymmetric space group R3. Attempts to refine the structure in the centrosymmetric alternative were unsuccessful. Examination of the results with platon also suggested that the space group assignment was correct. Finally, the Flack parameter of 0.04(4) is consistent with the non-centrosymmetric space group. The pyridyl group of this structure is statistically disordered over two sites, rotating by ca. 35° about the N1–C3 vector, with approximate populations of 0.80:0.20.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Results and discussions</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Syntheses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Compounds were synthesized using conventional hydrothermal methods, which are routinely applied in the isolation of organic–inorganic composite materials. At these temperature ranges, typically 120–250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the reactants are solubilized while retaining their structural features in the product phases, exploiting the self assembly of products from these soluble precursors . Under these crystallization conditions, problems associated with different solubilities of organic and inorganic starting materials are minimized, allowing for introduction of a variety of different organic and/or inorganic precursors, as well as organic and/or inorganic structure-directing or charge-balancing reagents. Such conditions may also allow for the isolation of kinetic rather than thermodynamically favored products.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussions
Syntheses
Compounds were synthesized using conventional hydrothermal methods, which are routinely applied in the isolation of organic–inorganic composite materials. At these temperature ranges, typically 120–250°C, the reactants are solubilized while retaining their structural features in the product phases, exploiting the self assembly of products from these soluble precursors . Under these crystallization conditions, problems associated with different solubilities of organic and inorganic starting materials are minimized, allowing for introduction of a variety of different organic and/or inorganic precursors, as well as organic and/or inorganic structure-directing or charge-balancing reagents. Such conditions may also allow for the isolation of kinetic rather than thermodynamically favored products.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were isolated as minor components from polycrystalline mixtures whose major phase was the previously described [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)(PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)] . Attempts to prepare pure samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> by modifying stoichiometries, changes in reaction temperature and varying pH proved unsuccessful. Consequently, while samples of sufficient purity for elemental analysis could be obtained by flotation techniques, samples for magnetic susceptibility studies could not be obtained without trace amounts of the highly magnetic [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)(PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)] phase.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Both 1 and 2 were isolated as minor components from polycrystalline mixtures whose major phase was the previously described [Co2(OH)(PO4)] . Attempts to prepare pure samples of 1 and 2 by modifying stoichiometries, changes in reaction temperature and varying pH proved unsuccessful. Consequently, while samples of sufficient purity for elemental analysis could be obtained by flotation techniques, samples for magnetic susceptibility studies could not be obtained without trace amounts of the highly magnetic [Co2(OH)(PO4)] phase.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The only significant differences in the syntheses of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were the pH values of the reactions and the temperatures. The importance of pH in determining product composition of hydrothermal reactions has been noted previously , and in this case the lower pH of the reaction for compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is reflected in the protonation of the phosphate group.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The structure of the second phase [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(4-pt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HOPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), shown in

However, in this instance, the structure is constructed from cobalt(II)-hydrogen phosphate layers, linked through the 4-pt ligands into the overall framework. As illustrated in b, each layer contains {Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">6+</ce:sup> linear trinuclear secondary building units. Each of these triads is linked to four adjacent clusters through {HOPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> tetrahedra, each of which bridges two Co sites of a given triad and one of an adjacent triad and projects a pendant {P–OH} group into an intralamellar cavity. Adjacent pairs of cobalt centers in a triad are bridged by N1,N2-coordinated 4-pt ligands, and the terminal cobalt sites also bond to pyridyl nitrogen donors. The central cobalt atom of the linear triad exhibits {CoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} coordination geometry through bonding to two phosphate oxygen donors, two <ce:italic>trans-</ce:italic>situated tetrazolate nitrogen donors from two 4-pt ligands and two <ce:italic>trans-</ce:italic>bridging aqua ligands. In contrast, the peripheral cobalt sites exhibit <ce:italic>cis-</ce:italic>{CoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} geometry, bonding to two phosphate oxygen donors, a tetrazolate N-donor, a pyridyl N-donor, and bridging and terminal aqua ligand.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The structure of the second phase [Co3(H2O)4(4-pt)2(HOPO3)2](2), shown in 
, is also three-dimensional. However, in this instance, the structure is constructed from cobalt(II)-hydrogen phosphate layers, linked through the 4-pt ligands into the overall framework. As illustrated in b, each layer contains {Co3(H2O)4}6+ linear trinuclear secondary building units. Each of these triads is linked to four adjacent clusters through {HOPO3}2− tetrahedra, each of which bridges two Co sites of a given triad and one of an adjacent triad and projects a pendant {P–OH} group into an intralamellar cavity. Adjacent pairs of cobalt centers in a triad are bridged by N1,N2-coordinated 4-pt ligands, and the terminal cobalt sites also bond to pyridyl nitrogen donors. The central cobalt atom of the linear triad exhibits {CoO4N2} coordination geometry through bonding to two phosphate oxygen donors, two trans-situated tetrazolate nitrogen donors from two 4-pt ligands and two trans-bridging aqua ligands. In contrast, the peripheral cobalt sites exhibit cis-{CoO4N2} geometry, bonding to two phosphate oxygen donors, a tetrazolate N-donor, a pyridyl N-donor, and bridging and terminal aqua ligand.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0070" view="all">A recurrent theme of the structural chemistry of the general system M(II)tetrazolate/anion where M(II)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Co, Ni, Cu, etc. is the presence of embedded transition metal/tetrazolate clusters as architectural motifs. In the case of the compounds of this study, both exhibit trinuclear Co(II) building blocks; however, it should be noted that these substructures are quite distinct. In the case of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> a triangular trinuclear core is observed, while <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is composed of linear building units, revealing a structural diversity dependent upon hydrothermal reaction conditions and starting materials.</ce:para>

In the case of 1 a triangular trinuclear core is observed, while 2 is composed of linear building units, revealing a structural diversity dependent upon hydrothermal reaction conditions and starting materials.

In the case of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, phosphate provides not only a μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-oxygen donor at the center of a cobalt triad, but also three bridging oxygen atoms of the tetrahedron so that each phosphate bridges to six cobalt centers from neighboring triads, a structural variant new to the library of {M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O)} cores.</ce:para>

Conclusions
Hydrothermal methods have been exploited in the preparation of two cobalt(II) phosphate phases incorporating 4-pyridyltetrazolate as an organic component, resulting in isolation of two novel three-dimensional structures of [Co3(4-pt)3(PO4)] (1) and [Co3(H2O)4(4-pt)2(HOPO3)2] (2). The structure of 1 exhibits a recurrent structural building block, the {M3(μ3-O)} subunit, most commonly encountered as the {M3(μ3-oxo)} and {M3(μ3-hydroxo)} moieties. In the case of compound 1, this subunit is present as part of an inorganic {Co3(PO4)}
n

3

n

+ chain. The expansion into three-dimensions is accomplished through the bridging dipodal 4-pyridyltetrazolate ligands.

The structural variety encountered for this compositionally simple system reflects a number of structural determinants. Most prominent among these are the variable protonation possibilities for the H<ce:italic>

While allowing a rich structural chemistry, such factors render the chemistry rather unpredictable, such that the extensive hydrothermal parameter space requires continuing exploration. A more systematic understanding of the complex chemistry will evolve as the structural data base for these systems expands.</ce:para>
